ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Other learning come from online assignments such as papers or readings to complete for the class.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course has been eye-opening and very informative. I have gained a lot of knowledge and perspective from taking this course.

This course was a great way to polish my writing skills and elevate them to the college level. The course also helped solidify discussion skills and taught a lot about different languages around the gobe.

Deeper analytical skills when dealing with written pieces; better argumentative skills; deciphering what is "good" writing and what "isn't"; more knowledge on world language politics and always seeing both sides of an argument

How to read large texts within a time constraint, time management, confidence to speak up during the discussion, how to write a research paper, an argumentative paper, and an analysis paper (all including the process).

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The readings and discussions were very entertaining and interesting. I always found myself deeply invested in class readings. Students did not really enjoy the VoiceThread component of the class, but the teacher realized that in our midterm reflection and decided to remove them, which shows empathy and understanding on the professor's side.
The course was overall pretty strong! Some assignments would get repetitive, but I guess that happens with most classes.

Strengths: very open to discussion and allow everyone to express their opinions; professor/teacher always open to suggestions and finding ways to better teach his students; extremely first-year friendly

Weaknesses: not really much that I can think of to be honest, but maybe just a few activities or homework that wasn't really meaningful?

Strengths: small class, easy to make friends, easy to talk to the professor
Weakness: nothing except for the virtual format

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: All practices allowed for virtual engagement.
The class succeeded pretty well over zoom. Discussions would sometimes be a little harder to jump into than it would normally be in person, but that is a little uncontrollable.
The class did its best under our circumstances.

Success: Making discussion engaging, very fun introduction games during the first week, and efficient use of breakout rooms
Could be improved: more breakout rooms

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Any student interested in getting a more global perspective on the world should take this course. This course, while named World Language Politics, discusses culture, tradition, and the importance of language in all areas of life. This course truly transforms how one might see language -- from a medium of conversation to a choice of living.
I would recommend this course to other students. I believe taking writing courses is extremely valuable and this class specifically was a very interesting lens through which to pursue writing.

YES, this is an amazing class for everyone! Anyone who is interested in anything related to global stuff, like international geopolitics, culture, language, history, geography, I highly recommend this course. A great way to further pursue your passions while also improving your writing, which is extremely important in this field.

Absolutely yes! Carson is a great teaching fellow who understands the student's struggles and is very lenient. He gives constructive feedback for your writing which helps you to improve your paper greatly and improve the way you approach your writing. Always encouraging and very knowledgeable on the topic. Best class by far.
